awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Lithosphere-scale anisotropic imaging across the Eastern North American Margin's ocean-continent transition
awd_abstract_narration:
The cycle of continent formation and subsequent breakup to build oceans is an essential aspect of plate tectonics and is one of the fundamental processes that shape the planet. Yet, there are several details of continental rifting that continue to elude us. Rifted margins, such as that which comprises the entire east coast of the United States, represent the contact between continental crust and oceanic crust that is formed during, and after, the breakup (in this case, the Atlantic Ocean formed as Africa moved away). These margins retain a record of the processes that led up to, coincided with, and followed continental breakup. This project will utilize existing onshore and offshore seismic data to study in detail the deformation that produced the modern day eastern U.S. The results will aid in assessing contemporary hazard and risks along the margin. This project supports the training of a graduate student at the University of California at Santa Barbara and at least one undergraduate student at the University of Arizona. It also supports outreach activities to several high schools in North Carolina that hosted seismic instruments that recorded earthquake data used in the analyses.   


This project aims to shed light on two fundamental scientific questions related to the structure, evolution, and on-going dynamics associated with the eastern North American passive rift margin (ENAM): 1) What is the structure of the lithosphere from top to bottom across the ocean-continent transition and how was it shaped by rifting processes? 2) What is the history of deformation both within and seaward of the passive margin, and how is present-day mantle flow controlled by the margin's structure? Depth-constrained 3-D anisotropic velocity models will be produced of the ENAM from crust to below the lithosphere-asthenosphere boundary (LAB). By employing different imaging techniques in sequence, we will create a suite of complementary models: a) 3-D isotropic shear velocity model from inversion of ambient noise and earthquake-generated surface waves; b) 1-D high-resolution velocity profiles using dispersion curves inverted jointly with S-p and P-s receiver functions sensitive to crust and mantle discontinuities; c) 3-D finite-frequency body-wave azimuthal anisotropy tomography using the surface wave tomography as a starting model. These models will be jointly interpreted to refine estimates of crustal thickness and LAB character across the margin in the context of geodynamical rifting models, as well as to understand deformational flow during rifting and margin maturation to the present day.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project outcomes

The eastern North American margin (ENAM) represents the type-locale for passive rifted margins. It has been relatively undisturbed since the breakup of Pangaea (roughly 200 million year ago), so retains a detailed history of the processes that lead to its formation. By looking at the ENAM, we answer important questions related to the fundamental processes of continental breakup, rift-initiation, and early opening of an ocean basin. For these reasons, the ENAM was the focus of a community-wide initiative that aimed to collect, for the first time, data from both the onshore and offshore parts of the passive margin. This drew such strong community support that it was the target site for the GeoPRISMS program. This made the eastern North American margin an ideal study target for foundational advances in understanding plate tectonics.

Intellectual Merit:

We made several significant advances in imaging the structure, deformation history, and dynamics surrounding the eastern North American margin from the crust to well beneath the plate. Our primary outcomes include:

1) We created a 3-dimentional shear velocity model of the whole margin that solves for both seismic wave speed and seismic anisotropy. From the wave speed, we were able to image detailed structures going all the way down beneath the plate in both the continental and oceanic regions. From the anisotropy, we were able to constrain deformation history and the active flow beneath the eastern North American margin. Solving both together is very challenging, but in doing so we were able to learn far more than if they had been attempted individually.

2) We further examined anisotropy along ENAM by studying how surface waves scatter along the margin. We measured quasi-Love scattering along the eastern seaboard in a variety of frequencies. We found a strong change in the dynamics of the mantle right at the boundary from the ocean onto the continent. Our results help settle an outstanding question related to the margin, which was “are anisotropy results related to the continent being ripped apart or to modern day mantle dynamics?”

3) We also produced a new 3D shear velocity model of the continental plate, from the coast past the Appalachian Mountains into the North American interior. This model focused on imaging the deepest structures of the plate. We employed a cutting-edge approach that simultaneously incorporated multiple datasets using a Bayesian statistical framework with methodological breakthroughs for efficient computation. This was the first-time scattered waves had been incorporated into such a model along the margin providing the sharpest images to date.

Broader Impacts:

This project trained a graduate student at U. Delaware, who is pursuing a career in the geosciences. It also trained two undergraduate students (at U. Delaware and at U. Arizona) who gained STEM experience and are now both employed in STEM fields. Components of this project were incorporated into graduate and undergraduate courses at U. Delaware as well as shared to the wider public through the U. Delaware organized Coast Day. The technical improvements made as a direct outcome of this project have helped improve offshore seismic data processing by many scientists across the field. Finally, our results have helped reshape how many communities think about the evolution and structure of the eastern North American margin, as well as passive margins worldwide.
